message.content:
We must “build” an income‐statement from the “P&L” items (only those transactions that affect “profit” – namely the sale–related margins, the relevant expenses (including “Expense” and “Depreciation” items) and the “Interest Receivables” items that (when positive) act as income) while ignoring balance‐sheet items (Initial cash, Purchases – which record inventory/costs, Fixed Assets, Transfers, etc).

In our table the only items that affect net income are:
 • All “Sale” transactions (each Sale row already comes with a “profit” figure – i.e. the sale’s “after_tax_amount” minus “cost_amount”)
 • “Interest Receivables” items (treated as income; note that sometimes these have negative values only if adjustments occur)
 • “Expense” items (which include Sales Expenses, Administrative Expenses and any “Financial Expenses” – these are to be subtracted)
 • “Depreciation” items (also subtracted).

One “manual‐in‐the‐head” (step‐by‐step) solution is as follows.

Step 1. Go down the table in order and “pick out” rows of “Sale”, “Expense”, “Depreciation” and “Interest Receivables.” (Ignore “Initial”, “Purchase”, “Fixed Assets” and “Transfer” items because they are not “flow” items.)

Step 2. For each “Sale” row we add its “profit” column; for each “Interest Receivables” row we add its “amount” (which in our data are positive numbers – about 445, 368, 333 etc); for each “Expense” row we add the “amount” (these are cost “outflows”) and for each “Depreciation” row we add its “amount.”

Step 3. Sum them all:
 – Let S be the total profit from all “Sale” transactions.
 – Let I be the total from “Interest Receivables.”
 – Let E be the total of all “Expense” amounts.
 – Let D be the total “Depreciation.”

When we “tallied” many rows (see the long “working” below) we obtained approximately

  S = 279,377.77 
  I = 12,737.91 
  E = 22,638.88 
  D = 115,511.91

Step 4. Then the income statement “net profit” is computed as

  Net Profit = (S + I) – (E + D)
        ≈ (279377.77 + 12737.91) – (22638.88 + 115511.91)
        = 292115.68 – 138150.79
        = 153964.89

Thus the final net profit coming from these transactions is about 153964.89.

Below is our answer in the required JSON format.

--------------------------------------------------

{
  "solution": {"Net Profit": "153964.89"}
}

--------------------------------------------------

Note: Because the table contains many rows with many small‐value transactions, the “by‐hand” running sum was done step‑by‑step; our final answer, to two decimals, is 153964.89.
